If you take one thing away from this: if you're trying to figure out how much $$ you saved on taxes this year, compare your tax liability year over year, not the size of your refund!

If you like ice-cream (& ice-cream puns), and have questions about your tax refund vs. your tax liability, this video is for you:

 https://www.wsj.com/video/series/talking-taxes/will-your-2019-tax-refund-be-sweeter-than-usual/2B1907C9-4DE9-4696-B4E2-22C7FC95F20C¬†‚Ä¶ https://twitter.com/RepTomRice/status/1096472347375255553¬†‚Ä¶

The size of your refund doesn't tell you if your tax bill was higher or lower. A smaller refund means you kept more of YOUR money that you worked for every pay-period instead of sending it up to bureaucrats in Washington.

Some of my friends across the aisle are missing the mark when it comes to tax reform & refunds. Let's clear this up. Your tax refund reflects how much you overpaid in taxes during the year. It's not a bonus check, it's a return of the money you loaned to the gov interest-free.

It also includes targeted tax relief provisions that will ease the financial burden of covering unexpected costs like home repairs or temporary housing after a disaster. Learn more: https://rice.house.gov/index.cfm?p=press-releases&id=351FE5F7-E05C-455B-9C7D-B6B3EFFBC5FF¬†‚Ä¶

I wanted to take away the guessing and provide people with a degree of certainty during an otherwise uncertain time. The 2018 Natural Disasters Tax Relief Act creates an automatic 60-day tax deadline extension after a Presidentially Declared Disaster.

Hurricane Matthew made landfall in South Carolina just a few days before a tax filing deadline. Hurricane Florence hit us in the middle of a tax filing season. My constituents have had to deal with this uncertainty more than once.
